messageBody:
On a current project, we have a ParameterValidator, that knows about
parameter names and allowed values. We test that the ParameterValidator
does the right thing, if called correctly. Our Value Objects, where the
parameter checking is usually used, do not have explicit tests. This is
the team's choice and not necessarily my choice. (I don't disagree, but
I wanted to point out that this is why I do with my current team, and
not necessarily what I would do in general.) We generally rely on
testing the classes that use our Value Objects to find bugs in using
the ParameterValidator.

This is a common problem for me: suppose there is a CentralClass that
is well-tested. Suppose there are 100 classes that use CentralClass,
because it provides a widely-used service. Parameter validation is a
good example of this. Logging is another. Testing that each class uses
CentralClass correctly results in redundant tests, or at least, very
similar tests. These classes generally have nothing in common except
that they use CentralClass, so there is no clean way to factor out the
common tests: there is no common interface that all these classes
implement that allow us to use the AbstractUseCase pattern. My current
inclination is test until fear becomes boredom, then add tests only as
bugs are found. Any other opinions?

Composition in test cases? Has anyone done this in a clean way? I kinda
want a mixin test case, I think. I have to get away from Java. :)
